title: Managing Blood Pressure
content: The role of hypertension in chronic disease and tips for lowering blood pressure were discussed. The standards on hypertension might need to be revised to ensure people's kidneys have a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) above 40 at the age of 100. A blood pressure of 120 over 80 is preferred, but if it’s 135 over 85, nutritional and exercise related maneuvers should be the first approach. Dietary changes can reduce blood pressure. Blood pressure can be fixed by diet— reducing salt, picking healthier foods, and exercising.

title: Use of Antihypertensive Medication
content: When someone's blood pressure reaches 140 over 90, if they can’t lower their blood pressure by dietary means, they should go on an antihypertensive medication because it will provide protection over time. However, there is no evidence that antihypertensives provide long term benefit to patients with a blood pressure of 135/85. The trouble with defining hypertension at a lower level, is it implies that antihypertensive should be used at those lower levels and the evidence is not strong enough to warrant that.

title: Challenges in Defining Hypertension
content: If one compares people with a blood pressure of 135/85 to 120/80 over five years, it’s not going to reveal enough of a difference. This creates a problem with how the guidelines are created, but it shouldn’t confuse the underlying physiology. If more stringent definitions of hypertension are used, then suddenly a very large number of adults have hypertension. And if you then say that they need treatment for it in terms of like an antihypertensive, then you’re talking about probably the majority of the population.

title: Reducing Insulin Resistance
content: The treatment for hypertension might be to reduce insulin resistance. However, drugs aren’t great at reducing metabolic syndrome.

title: Professional Experience
content: A professor of medicine in the Department of Nephrology at the University of Colorado since 2008 and has spent the last 19 years being a division chief across three very prestigious medical schools. Has well over 700 publications in JAMA, New England Journal of Medicine, Science, etc. Has lectured across 40 countries, authored two books, including The Fat Switch, and has been funded extensively by the National Institute of Health (NIH).

title: Research Focus
content: Primary focus in research has been on the mechanisms causing kidney disease. Became interested in the connection between fructose (and fructose metabolism) and obesity, diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, and metabolic disease.
